name: Yin Yoga
summary: A slow-paced style of yoga with passive, long-held postures that target deep connective tissues, fascia, and joints, promoting flexibility, relaxation, and meditative awareness.
description: Yin Yoga is a contemplative practice that emphasizes stillness and long-held, passive stretches (typically 2–7 minutes per pose). Rooted in Taoist philosophy and influenced by Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), Yin Yoga aims to balance the body's energy by stimulating meridians while enhancing flexibility in connective tissues such as fascia, ligaments, and joints. It complements more active (yang) practices like Vinyasa or power yoga. Practitioners report benefits including increased range of motion, reduced stress, improved circulation, and deeper mindfulness. Yin Yoga is widely practiced in wellness, rehabilitation, and integrative health contexts.

items: Supportive therapy for chronic musculoskeletal pain

sections.text: Yin Yoga applies gentle, sustained tension to connective tissues, stimulating collagen remodeling and improving fascial hydration and elasticity. Long holds encourage relaxation of muscles, allowing deeper access to fascia, ligaments, and joints. Neurologically, extended postures promote parasympathetic dominance, reducing stress responses. In TCM theory, Yin Yoga stimulates energy flow along meridians, supporting systemic balance.

sections.preparation: Quiet environment with yoga mat and optional props (bolsters, blocks, blankets).
procedure: Begin with centering and breath awareness.
Move into supported, passive poses held for 2–7 minutes.
Maintain mindfulness and non-reactivity to sensations.
Transition slowly between postures, concluding with relaxation or meditation.
